choices.text: Possibility of laryngotracheobronchitis should be considered
Flexible bronchoscopy is the procedure of choice
Focal hyperinflation with reduced or absent breath sounds suggests foreign body aspiration
Hyperinflation is often produced by the Ball-Valve Mechanism in complete obstruction due to a foreign body

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child was playing and suddenly developed an acute onset of breathing difficulty. There is no history of any such symptom in the past or in the family. Chest X-ray shows unilateral hyperinflation of the right lung. What is the correct interpretation?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:
Foreign body aspiration (FBA) is a common emergency in young children, especially those aged 1–3 years. The presentation is often acute, following a choking episode or while playing/eating.

In this case, sudden onset respiratory distress in a previously healthy child, with unilateral hyperinflation on chest X-ray, strongly suggests a partially obstructing foreign body. This occurs due to a ball-valve mechanism, where air enters during inspiration but cannot escape during expiration, leading to air trapping and hyperinflation. (Option D ruled out)

Unilateral decreased or absent breath sounds, especially with hyperresonance, further supports this diagnosis. This is a classic radiological and clinical clue pointing to foreign body aspiration, particularly in the right bronchial tree, which is more vertical and wider.

Explanation of other options:

Possibility of laryngotracheobronchitis should be considered (Option A): Laryngotracheobronchitis (croup) typically presents with barking cough, stridor, and fever, which are not present here. It also doesn’t cause unilateral hyperinflation.

Flexible bronchoscopy is the procedure of choice (Option B): Flexible bronchoscopy is useful for diagnosis, but in pediatric foreign body aspiration, rigid bronchoscopy is the gold standard as it allows both visualization and removal of the object under controlled airway conditions.

choices.text: Nasal wash for influenza and RSV

questions.text: A 2.5-year-old child presents with high-grade fever, barking cough, and stridor while crying. The child accepts fluids normally. On examination, the respiratory rate is 34/min and temperature is 102°F. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
The child presents with classic signs of mild croup (laryngotracheobronchitis)-barking cough, stridor on crying (but not at rest), and no signs of respiratory distress or poor feeding.

Croup is most commonly caused by parainfluenza virus and typically affects children between 6 months to 5 yrs of age (peak at 2 yrs). It is usually preceded by an upper respiratory tract infection (URTI), with initial symptoms like rhinorrhea, nasal congestion, and low-grade fever which progress to barking cough and stridor, over 1-2 days.

Oral dexamethasone is the treatment of choice even in mild croup, as it reduces laryngeal edema and prevents progression. It also decreases need for hospitalization and use of nebulized medications.

Assessment of Severity of Acute Laryngotracheobronchitis:

Management of Croup:

  • Effectiveness of Oral Corticosteroids: Oral corticosteroids are effective in viral croup as they reduce laryngeal mucosa edemathrough their anti-inflammatory action. They are beneficial even in mild croup, reducing the hospitalization rates, duration of illness, and the need for adjunctive treatments like nebulized epinephrine.
  • Indications for Nebulized Epinephrine: Nebulised epinephrine is indicated for moderate to severe croup, including cases with moderate to severe stridor at rest, possible need for intubation, respiratory distress, and hypoxia. It is not typically used for mild croup. (Option A ruled out)
  • Antibiotics are not Indicated in typical cases of croup, which is viral in origin, most commonly due to parainfluenza virus (Option D ruled out)
  • Hospitalization:Consider hospitalization for cases with worsening symptoms, difficulty breathing, dehydration, severe stridor at rest, hypoxia, cyanosis, depressed mental status, poor oral intake, or when reliable observation is necessary.
  • Additional Information: Nonprescription cough and cold medications should not be used in children younger than 4 years of age. Heliox (a helium-oxygen mixture) may be considered in severe croupcases when intubation is being considered, although evidence is inconclusive.

Explanation of Other Options:

Nasal wash for influenza and RSV (Option C): Not useful in routine cases of classic croup presentation. It would be considered in atypical or hospitalized cases with diagnostic uncertainty.

questions.text: Most common pathogen responsible for acute bacterial tracheitis is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:
Acute bacterial tracheitis (also known as pseudomembranous croup) is a rare but potentially life-threatening bacterial infection of the upper airway, commonly seen in children.

  • It often follows a viral upper respiratory infection or viral croup and presents with severe airway obstruction, high-grade fever, and toxic appearance, which help distinguish it from typical viral croup.
  • The most commonly isolated pathogen in acute bacterial tracheitis is Staphylococcus aureus, including methicillin-resistant strains (MRSA). Other organisms reported include Haemophilus influenzae, Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A), Neisseria spp., and Moraxella catarrhalis, but aureus remains the most frequent.
  • Due to improved vaccination (e.g., against H. influenzae type b) and corticosteroid use for croup, bacterial tracheitis has become a relatively more frequent cause of pediatric airway emergencies, often requiring intubation and PICU admission.

Explanation of other options:

Influenza virus (Option A): Though viral infections often precede bacterial tracheitis, the influenza virus is not the primary pathogen in bacterial tracheitis. It may predispose the airway to secondary bacterial infection.

Parainfluenza virus (Option B): Parainfluenza virus is the most common cause of viral croup, not bacterial tracheitis. Tracheitis is a secondary bacterial infection.

Streptococcus pyogenes (Option D): S. pyogenes can be isolated in some cases, but it is not the most common organism. It is more often associated with tonsillitis or scarlet fever.

questions.text: A child is a known case of VSD with corrective surgery planned after 3 months. He had one episode of severe bronchiolitis last year requiring hospitalization. Now, there is another outbreak of RSV infection in the community. What prophylactic agent would you consider in this child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
Children with hemodynamically significant congenital heart disease (CHD), such as ventricular septal defect (VSD), are considered high-risk for severe respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) disease. This risk is further elevated in children with a history of hospitalization due to bronchiolitis, as seen in this case.

Palivizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody directed against the F (fusion) protein of RSV, which is essential for viral entry into host cells.

  • It is used prophylactically during RSV season in high-risk infants and children to reduce the severity and incidence of RSV infections.
  • Recommended dose: 15 mg/kg intramuscularly once a month, typically during RSV season (5 monthly doses).
  • It has been shown to significantly reduce hospitalization rates in high-risk groups such as preterm infants, those with bronchopulmonary dysplasia, and those with CHD.

Explanation of Other Options:

Ribavirin (Option B) is an antiviral agent used therapeutically in select severe RSV cases but is not recommended for prophylaxis.

Ribavirin + Palivizumab (Option C) combination is not used for prophylaxis. Ribavirin is reserved for severe, established RSV infections and is not routinely combined with palivizumab for preventive purposes.

Low dose montelukast (Option D): Montelukast is a leukotriene receptor antagonist used in asthma and allergic rhinitis, not in RSV prevention.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presents to the clinic with concerns of congestion, rhinorrhea, frequent sneezing, and an itchy throat for the last three weeks. On examination, his turbinates are swollen and pale, and there is darkening of the skin below both eyelids. What is the best treatment for his condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:
This child presents with classic symptoms of allergic rhinitis: nasal congestion, sneezing, rhinorrhea, itchy throat, and physical signs including pale, swollen turbinates and infraorbital darkening ("allergic shiners").

Allergic rhinitis is an IgE-mediated hypersensitivity reaction to environmental allergens.

Typical features include:

  • Symptoms: Sneezing, rhinorrhea, nasal congestion, itchy throat or eyes, postnasal drip
  • Signs:
    • Pale, swollen turbinates
    • Infraorbital darkening ("allergic shiners")
    • Nasal crease (from frequent rubbing – "allergic salute")
    • Dennie-Morgan lines (extra skin folds under eyes)
    • Cobblestoning of the posterior pharynx – represents lymphoid hyperplasia from chronic postnasal drip

Intranasal corticosteroids, such as fluticasone, are the first-line treatment for moderate to severe allergic rhinitis and have been proven to be more effective than oral antihistamines in reducing nasal inflammation and symptoms. They act by decreasing local mucosal inflammation and have minimal systemic absorption.

Side effects may include:

  • Nasal dryness or irritation
  • Epistaxis (especially if used improperly)

Allergen avoidance and environmental control measures (e.g., dust mite control) are also essential adjuncts.

Explanation of Other Options:

Intranasal cromolyn (Option A): While cromolyn is a mast cell stabilizer that can be used prophylactically, it is less effective than intranasal corticosteroids and requires frequent dosing (4–6 times/day), limiting compliance.

Oral loratadine (Option C): Loratadine is a second-generation oral antihistamine useful for mild symptoms but is less effective than intranasal steroids, particularly for nasal congestion.

Oral montelukast (Option D): Montelukast is a leukotriene receptor antagonist, occasionally used in allergic rhinitis, especially if there is coexistent asthma, but it is not first-line therapy and has lower efficacy compared to intranasal corticosteroids.

choices.text: Start oral antibiotics and review in 48 hours

questions.text: A 2-year-old child with a weight of 11 kg presents with moderate-grade fever, cough, chest indrawing, and a respiratory rate of 38/min. What is the optimal management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The child does not have fast breathing (RR < 40/min for age 12–59 months) but has chest indrawing.
  • As per both WHO/IMCI and the latest IMNCI program, the presence of eitherfast breathing or chest indrawing indicates Pneumonia
  • Pneumonia without danger signs (e.g., inability to feed, convulsions, lethargy, vomiting) is treated at home with oral antibiotics—oral amoxicillin for 5 days is recommended. (Option A ruled out)
  • The child should be reviewed in 48 hours to assess the response to therapy.
  • No need for hospital admission or IV antibiotics, as there are no danger signs. (Option C ruled out)
  • Routine chest X-ray is not indicated in typical cases of pneumonia without complications or atypical presentation. (Option D ruled out)

IMNCI Classification of Cough or Difficult Breathing (2 months to 5 years):

Definition of Fast Breathing (by age):

questions.text: The following are common viral causes of pneumonia in children except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:
The most common viral causes of pneumonia in children include:

  • Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) – most frequent cause in infants
  • Adenovirus – can cause severe lower respiratory tract infection (Option A ruled out)
  • Influenza virus (A and B) – seasonal outbreaks, can lead to serious complications (Option B ruled out)
  • Parainfluenza virus – also associated with croup and bronchitis (Option C ruled out)
  • Rhinovirus, Human metapneumovirus, and Coronavirus (non-SARS-CoV-2) are other known pathogens

On the other hand, Coxsackie A virus is not typically implicated in pneumonia. It primarily affects the mucous membranes and skin, causing:

  • Herpangina
  • Hand, foot, and mouth disease
  • Acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis
  • Upper respiratory tract disease

Coxsackie B virus, by contrast, is more invasive and systemic, causing:

  • Myocarditis
  • Pericarditis
  • Hepatitis
  • Aseptic meningitis
  • Pleurodynia (Bornholm disease)

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with nasal discharge. He has allergic rhinitis, well-controlled with cetirizine during spring and fall. Two weeks ago, he developed fever (peak 38.4°C for 2 days) and malaise, followed by a persistent runny nose. After about 1 week, the discharge became thicker and turned from clear to white. He is afebrile today with stable vitals. The examination shows nasal congestion, white discharge from the right nares, and swollen turbinates on the left. Which of the following most supports a diagnosis of acute bacterial sinusitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
The most significant finding that supports a diagnosis of acute bacterial sinusitis (ABS) in this child is the persistence of symptoms beyond 10 days without clinical improvement. The child had a typical viral prodrome followed by persistent rhinorrhea and congestion for two weeks, which is a classic presentation.

Diagnostic criteria for ABS include:

  • Persistence of nasal congestion, rhinorrhea (any quality), and daytime cough ≥10 days without improvement
  • Severe symptoms: Fever ≥39°C and purulent nasal discharge for ≥3 days
  • Worsening symptoms after initial improvement or new onset of fever, nasal discharge, and cough (so-called double sickening)

Explanation of other options:

Fever characterization (Option B): The child had a low-grade fever (38.4°C) that lasted only 2 days. The diagnostic criterion for ABS includes fever ≥39°C lasting ≥3 days, which is not met.

Predisposing condition (Option C): Allergic rhinitis is a risk factor, but it does not confirm diagnosis. Predisposing conditions increase the risk, but diagnosis relies on clinical course and symptom duration.

Quality of discharge (Option D): Mucopurulent discharge can be seen in both viral and bacterial infections. Therefore, discharge color alone is not diagnostic of ABS.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with acute onset of fever, stridor, and respiratory distress. His neck X-ray is shown below. What is the appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:
This child presents with acute onset fever, stridor, and respiratory distress, and the lateral neck X-ray demonstrates the classic "thumb sign", which represents an enlarged epiglottis—highly suggestive of acute epiglottitis.

  • Acute epiglottitis is a life-threatening emergency caused most commonly by Haemophilus influenzae type B (Hib) in unvaccinated children. It leads to rapid airway obstruction due to inflammation and swelling of the epiglottis.
  • The first and most critical step in management is securing the airway, as these children are at imminent risk of complete airway obstruction.
  • Endotracheal intubation must be performed in a controlled setting (ideally in the OR or ICU) with facilities for emergency tracheostomy if intubation fails.
  • Once the airway is secured, IV antibiotics (e.g., ceftriaxone) and supportive therapy can be initiated.

Explanation of other options:

IV Dexamethasone 0.15 mg/kg (Option A): Corticosteroids may reduce inflammation but do not address the immediate risk of airway compromise, which must be prioritized in epiglottitis.

Racemic epinephrine nebulization (Option B): This is used in croup, not epiglottitis. It has no role in epiglottitis and may worsen distress if the airway is stimulated.

IV Ceftriaxone (Option C): Although ceftriaxone is the antibiotic of choice, initiating it before securing the airway is not recommended due to the risk of sudden deterioration.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common cause of bronchiolitis obliterans in children?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bronchiolitis obliterans (BO) is an uncommon form of obstructive lung disease that occurs as a result of a severe insult to the small airways and ultimately leads to fibrosis and obliteration of the bronchioles.

  • Epidemiology studies suggest that BO occurs frequently in children of Asian and South American descent.
  • In children, the leading cause of BO is infectious, with adenovirus (especially the more virulent serotypes 3, 7 and 21) being the most common offending agent.
  • BO also occurs in patients with lung or bone marrow transplants and in those with autoimmune disorders.
  • Other causes include toxic inhalation injury or aspiration, hypersensitivity pneumonitis, drug toxicity, and Stevens-Johnson syndrome, SJS.

Explanation of other options:

Liver transplant (Option A): BO is more classically associated with lung and hematopoietic stem cell transplantation, not liver transplants. Chronic graft-versus-host disease is a common trigger post-BMT.

SLE (Option B): Autoimmune diseases like SLE can cause BO, but this is much less common in children compared to post-infectious causes.

Mycoplasma (Option D): Mycoplasma pneumoniae can cause respiratory infections, but it is not the leading cause of bronchiolitis obliterans in children.

choices.text: Get a hemogram and throat swab done.

questions.text: A 5-month-old infant presents with intermittent stridor and mild dysphagia since birth. The stridor worsens when the child is lying supine or crying, and improves when the child is in the prone position or calm. The baby is otherwise feeding well and growing appropriately. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
This is a classic presentation of laryngomalacia, the most common cause of congenital stridor. It is caused by flaccid supraglottic structures, which collapse into the airway during inspiration.

Key clinical features include:

  • Onset in the first few weeks of life
  • Inspiratory stridor that worsens in the supine position, during crying or feeding, and improves in the prone or calm state
  • Mild dysphagia may occur, but most infants feed and grow well
  • Minimal to absent respiratory distress

On laryngoscopy, a hallmark finding is an omega (Ω)-shaped epiglottis, which folds inward during inspiration. The arytenoids and aryepiglottic folds may also be curled or floppy.

Since this child is otherwise thriving and not in respiratory distress, no intervention is required. Reassurance and observation are the best steps. Most cases resolve spontaneously by 12-18 months as the laryngeal structures mature.

Explanation of Other Options:

Evaluate radiographically (Option B): Radiologic evaluation is not necessary in classic, mild cases with typical history and no alarming features. Imaging is reserved for atypical or severe cases.

Sweat chloride test (Option C): This is used to diagnose cystic fibrosis, which presents with persistent cough, recurrent infections, failure to thrive, not isolated stridor.

Get a hemogram and throat swab done (Option D): These tests are useful in suspected infection, but there's no fever, acute symptoms, or evidence of infection here.

questions.text: Which among the following conditions presents in infancy with cyclic cyanosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

Bilateral choanal atresia is a congenital condition in which both posterior nasal apertures (choanae) are blocked, either by bone or membranous tissue.

  • Infants are obligate nasal breathers in the first few months of life, and this obstruction leads to severe respiratory distress and cyanosis.
  • The cyanosis occurs when the infant is quiet or feeding and attempting to breathe through the nose.
  • Crying relieves the obstruction by allowing air to pass through the mouth, leading to temporary improvement in oxygenation. Once the baby calms and closes the mouth again, cyanosis returns-this repetitive pattern is called "cyclic cyanosis."

It is a neonatal emergency and often associated with CHARGE syndrome (Coloboma, Heart defects, Atresia choanae, Retardation of growth/development, Genital anomalies, Ear abnormalities).

Explanation of other options:

Unilateral choanal atresia (Option B): Usually presents later in childhood with unilateral nasal discharge or obstruction. It is not severe enough to cause cyclic cyanosis in neonates, since one nostril remains patent.

Laryngomalacia (Option C): Presents with inspiratory stridor that worsens when the infant is supine or feeding, but does not typically cause cyclic cyanosis. The airway is patent, though partially collapsed.

Subglottic stenosis (Option D): A congenital or acquired narrowing of the airway below the vocal cords. Presents with biphasic stridor or respiratory distress, but cyclic cyanosis is not a hallmark feature.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is admitted to the hospital in respiratory distress due to pneumonia. This is her third admission in the past 6 months. At this time, you are suspecting cystic fibrosis (CF) and order a sputum culture. Which organism would be most consistent with a diagnosis of cystic fibrosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
The presence of Pseudomonas aeruginosa in the sputum of a child with recurrent lower respiratory infections is highly suggestive of cystic fibrosis (CF). This organism is rarely seen in the sputum of healthy children, but is commonly found in those with CF due to impaired mucociliary clearance, thickened secretions, and compromised innate airway immunity.

Over time, CF patients become colonized with pathogens such as:

  • Staphylococcus aureus (early)
  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa (increasingly with age, becoming chronic)
  • Burkholderia cepacia complex (less common but associated with poor prognosis)

The isolation of P. aeruginosa, especially in a child with recurrent pneumonias, is a red flag and warrants further diagnostic workup for CF (e.g., sweat chloride test, genetic testing).

Explanation of other options:

Streptococcus pneumoniae (Option A): While this is a common cause of community-acquired pneumonia, its presence is not specifically suggestive of CF. It is commonly seen in many pediatric infections.

Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Option B): Though TB can cause chronic respiratory symptoms, it is not commonly associated with CF, and its presence is not diagnostic.

Bacillus cereus (Option D): This is an uncommon respiratory pathogen and more often associated with food poisoning. Its presence in sputum is not indicative of CF.

questions.text:
Which among the following is/are true statements regarding sweat and pancreatic secretions chloride levels in Cystic Fibrosis?
1. Chloride excretion is increased in sweat
2. Chloride excretion is decreased in sweat
3. Chloride concentration is increased in pancreatic secretions
4. Chloride concentration is decreased in pancreatic secretions
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In Cystic Fibrosis- Chloride excretion is increased in sweat and is is decreased in pancreatic secretions.

questions.text: Involvement of the lungs in cystic fibrosis can be any of the following except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:
Cystic fibrosis (CF) primarily affects the lungs through obstruction of small airways by thick mucus, leading to chronic infection and inflammation. Over time, this results in structural lung damage and a range of pulmonary complications.

Common pulmonary manifestations of CF include:

  • Bronchiectasis (d/t chronic infection & inflammation) (Option B ruled out)
  • Bronchitis and bronchiolitis (recurrent and persistent d/t mucus plugging) (Option C ruled out)
  • Recurrent pneumonias
  • Pneumothorax (in advanced disease d/t ruptured bullae) (Option A ruled out)
  • Hemoptysis, mucoid impaction, cor pulmonale, respiratory failure, and reactive airway disease
  • Upper airway involvement: nasal polyps, chronic sinusitis
  • Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA) as a hypersensitivity reaction

Alveolitis refers to inflammation of the alveoli, which is not a typical or primary feature of cystic fibrosis. CF pathology primarily involves the bronchi and bronchioles, rather than alveolar inflammation.

choices.text: Insert a large bore needle on right side
Insert a large bore needle on left side
Arrange for an urgent chest X-ray, and meanwhile give high doses of inhaled oxygen

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath and chest pain. His heart rate is 120/min, blood pressure is 80/50 mmHg, and jugular venous pressure is elevated. Breath sounds are absent on one side, and his oxygen saturation is 70% despite receiving supplemental oxygen. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
This child presents with signs of tension pneumothorax, a medical emergency that occurs when air enters the pleural space and accumulates under pressure. This causes compression of the adjacent lung, mediastinal shift to the contralateral side, and impairs venous return by compressing the heart and great vessels, leading to refractory hypoxia and obstructive shock.

Clinical features of tension pneumothorax include:

  • Cyanosis, tachypnea, intercostal retractions
  • Asymmetric chest rise, contralateral tracheal deviation
  • Diminished or absent breath sounds on the affected side
  • Signs of shock: hypotension, tachycardia, raised JVP
  • Oxygen saturation remains low despite oxygen therapy

The next best step in management is emergent needle decompression using a large bore needle (usually 14–16G) in the second intercostal space, midclavicular line on the affected side, followed by chest tube (thoracostomy) insertion to provide definitive drainage.

  • In this scenario, as the breath sounds are absent on the right, decompression must be performed on the right.

Explanation of other options:

Insert a large bore needle on left side (Option B): Although needle decompression is the correct intervention, the right side is the affected side, as suggested by the absent breath sounds.

Arrange for an urgent chest X-ray and meanwhile give high doses of inhaled oxygen (Option C): Waiting for imaging in a suspected tension pneumothorax can be fatal. Diagnosis is clinical, and management must not be delayed.

Emergency tracheostomy to secure airway (Option D): Airway obstruction is not the issue here. This is not a case of upper airway compromise; tracheostomy is not indicated.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with persistent fever, cough, and respiratory distress for the past 7 days. A chest X-ray is taken and is shown below. On thoracocentesis, thick yellow pus is aspirated. Which of the following is the most common causative organism responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
The clinical and radiological features suggest empyema thoracis.

Empyema thoracis refers to the collection of pus within the pleural space, most commonly developing as a sequela of pneumonia, particularly in young children. In those aged under 3 years, the most common causative agent is Staphylococcus aureus.

It typically follows staphylococcal pneumonia, although other organisms like Streptococcus pneumoniae, Mycoplasma pneumoniae, and gram-negative bacilli can also lead to empyema.

Key diagnostic clues in this child include:

  • Persistent fever
  • Loculated pleural effusion on imaging
  • Pus aspirated on thoracocentesis

These point toward empyema thoracis rather than a simple parapneumonic effusion.

In empyema, the effusion is always exudative, with very high neutrophils, low glucose, low pH, and elevated LDH.

Features Differentiating Exudative From Transudative Pleural Effusion:

Radiology: Loculated effusion typically appears lenticular or septated. CT or ultrasound may show pleural thickening, septations, or split pleura sign.

Explanation of other options:

Escherichia coli (Option A): Rare cause in this age group. May be seen in immunocompromised or nosocomial cases, not commonly in community-acquired empyema in young children.

Streptococcus pneumoniae (Option B): Although S. pneumoniae is a common pneumonia pathogen, empyema is more commonly a sequela of staphylococcal pneumonia.

Klebsiella pneumoniae (Option C): Seen more often in hospital-acquired infections or in malnourished children. Not the leading community-acquired cause of empyema in this age group.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common location of aspirated foreign bodies going into the lower airway in children?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The right main bronchus is the most common site for aspirated foreign bodies in children (and adults) due to its distinct anatomical features. It is wider, shorter, and more vertically aligned than the left main bronchus, making it a more direct extension of the trachea. These features make it easier for inhaled objects to enter and lodge in the right bronchus rather than the left.

In contrast:

  • The left main bronchus is longer and more horizontal, which makes foreign body entry less likely. (Option B ruled out)
  • The trachea may transiently trap a foreign body, but it usually leads to either immediate expulsion via coughing or migration into a bronchus. (Option D ruled out)
  • Segmental bronchi like the left lower bronchus are rarely initial impaction sites. (Option A ruled out)

Foreign Body Aspiration in Children

Clinical Presentation:

  • Sudden-onset coughing, choking, wheezing
  • Unilateral decreased breath sounds

Diagnosis:

  • Chest X-ray may help, but most foreign bodies are radiolucent
  • Flexible bronchoscopy is sensitive for visualization, but not suitable for removal
  • Rigid bronchoscopy is both diagnostic and therapeutic.

Definitive Treatment:

  • As per Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Ed: The treatment of choice for airway foreign bodies is prompt endoscopic removal with rigid instruments by a specialist (otolaryngologist or pulmonologist).
    • Potential complications of rigid bronchoscopyinclude bronchospasm, desaturation, bleeding, and airway edema, in addition to the inherent risks of anesthesia.

Reference: 

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5556322/

choices.text: Intravenous Magnesium Sulphate can be considered

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl with a family history of bronchial asthma presents to the emergency department with a history of difficulty in breathing. She is sitting, not talking, and looks very anxious. Her oxygen saturation on 5 L of oxygen via a face mask is <90%. She is using accessory muscles and has no audible wheeze. She is a known asthmatic. She was playing outside when her mother found her crying with very shallow breathing. The mother administered 10 puffs of salbutamol via spacer before bringing her to the hospital. Which of the following will be effective in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
This child is exhibiting signs of life-threatening asthma, indicated by oxygen saturation <90% despite oxygen therapy, silent chest (no audible wheeze), severe respiratory distress, and inability to speak. These are critical red flags for impending respiratory failure.

For life-threatening asthma (previously termed status asthmaticus), all standard therapeutic measures should be initiated promptly. Management includes:

  • Oxygen supplementation
  • Subcutaneous injection of terbutaline or adrenaline
  • Nebulization with salbutamol, with or without ipratropium bromide
  • Intravenous hydrocortisone at a dose of 5 mg/kg
  • Transfer to the Pediatric ICU for close monitoring and escalation if necessary

If there is no clinical improvement or the patient's condition deteriorates, the following may be considered:

  • Slow IV infusion of magnesium sulfate (50 mg/kg)
  • Theophylline infusion as an alternative bronchodilator

If the patient remains unresponsive to these interventions, intubation and mechanical ventilation become the last resort.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an essential medication for acute asthma exacerbations?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:
Montelukast is a leukotriene receptor antagonist (LTRA) used in the long-term control of asthma. It helps reduce inflammation and bronchoconstriction but is not effective for acute symptom relief, making it unsuitable for the management of acute asthma exacerbations.

In contrast, the other three drugs (Salbutamol/Albuterol, Prednisolone, Ipratropium) are mainstays of acute asthma treatment.

Acute Asthma Exacerbation Management:

Long-Term Management of Pediatric Asthma:

Children ≥12 years: Managed similarly to adults.

Age 6 to 11 years: Stepwise management as follows.

questions.text: Pediatric airway is different from that of an adult in which aspect?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

Features of pediatric airway compared to an adult airway include:

  • Relatively larger tongue
  • Short epiglottis
  • Larynx is placed higher
  • Subglottic area is the narrowest part

Pediatric vs Adult Airway Anatomy:

Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4439709/
